verses.text: A false balance is detestable to the LORD, but a just weight is his delight.
verses.comment: This verse condemns dishonesty in business and upholds justice. Integrity in everyday dealings is not optional but central to righteousness, reflecting God’s own justice.

verses.text: When arrogance comes, then comes disgrace, but with the humble is wisdom.
verses.comment: Pride leads to downfall, as seen throughout Scripture. Humility opens one to wisdom, a recurring virtue in both Old and New Testament teaching.

verses.text: The integrity of the upright guides them, but the crookedness of traitors destroys them.
verses.comment: Righteousness is a light for the faithful, while treachery leads to ruin, echoing the biblical theme that the way of deceit ultimately fails.

verses.text: Riches do not profit in the day of wrath, but righteousness delivers from death.
verses.comment: Material possessions cannot buy deliverance before God; only a life lived in right relationship with Him offers true security, anticipating themes found in the teachings of Christ.

verses.text: The righteousness of the blameless makes their way straight, but the wicked fall by their own wickedness.
verses.comment: Living rightly brings clarity and guidance, while sin creates stumbling blocks. This is both a moral and spiritual reality—seen ultimately in the straight way Christ offers to His followers.

verses.text: The righteousness of the upright rescues them, but the treacherous are caught by their own desires.
verses.comment: Adherence to righteousness leads to deliverance, while sinful cravings ensnare the unfaithful. The theme builds toward a spiritual redemption fulfilled in Christ.

verses.text: When a wicked man dies, his hope perishes, and the expectation of power comes to nothing.
verses.comment: Worldly hopes without faith are ultimately empty. True hope endures beyond death, with the ultimate hope anchored in Christ’s resurrection.

verses.text: The righteous is delivered from trouble, and the wicked falls into it instead.
verses.comment: God’s justice ensures the eventual reversal of fortunes, a pattern foreshadowing the vindication of believers in Christ.

verses.text: By his mouth the godless destroys his neighbor, but by knowledge the righteous are rescued.
verses.comment: Words have the power to harm or to save. Righteous speech, informed by God’s wisdom, brings life (see also James 3:6–10).

verses.text: When the righteous prosper, the city rejoices, but when the wicked perish, there are shouts of joy.
verses.comment: A community is uplifted by righteous leaders, whose prosperity benefits all. This principle can be applied spiritually to Christ, whose reign brings rejoicing to the nations.

verses.text: Through the blessing of the upright a city is exalted, but by the mouth of the wicked it is torn down.
verses.comment: The collective influence of the righteous brings well-being to society, aligning with the call to be salt and light (Matthew 5:13–16).

verses.text: Whoever belittles his neighbor lacks sense, but a man of understanding keeps silent.
verses.comment: Restraint in speech demonstrates wisdom and respect for others, echoing Christ’s call to love one’s neighbor.

verses.text: A gossip reveals secrets, but a trustworthy person keeps a matter concealed.
verses.comment: Guarding confidences is a mark of integrity and charity, essential to Christian fellowship and community.

verses.text: Where there is no guidance, a people falls, but in an abundance of counselors there is safety.
verses.comment: Wise counsel is vital for proper governance and spiritual life. This verse foreshadows the value of authority and tradition in guiding the community of faith.

verses.text: Whoever puts up security for a stranger will surely suffer, but whoever hates striking hands in pledge is safe.
verses.comment: Caution is advised in financial dealings, warning against careless commitments that can lead to trouble.

verses.text: A gracious woman attains honor, and violent men attain riches.
verses.comment: True honor is linked to graciousness and virtue, not just the accumulation of wealth.

verses.text: A merciful man does good for his own soul, but the cruel man brings trouble on himself.
verses.comment: Mercy brings blessings to the merciful; this principle is echoed by Jesus in the Beatitudes.

verses.text: The wicked earns deceptive wages, but the one who sows righteousness reaps a true reward.
verses.comment: What one sows they will reap—either temporary gain for evil or lasting reward for righteousness.

verses.text: Whoever is steadfast in righteousness will have life, but he who pursues evil brings about his own death.
verses.comment: Righteousness is inseparably tied to life, prefiguring Jesus’ teaching that He himself is the way, the truth, and the life.

verses.text: Those with twisted hearts are detestable to the LORD, but those whose way is blameless are his delight.
verses.comment: God examines and delights in sincerity of heart, not mere appearances or words.

verses.text: Be sure of this: the evil person will not go unpunished, but the children of the righteous will be delivered.
verses.comment: God’s justice is unfailing. Blessing can flow through generations of the righteous, hinting at the value of faithfulness and spiritual inheritance.

verses.text: Like a gold ring in a pig's snout is a beautiful woman without discretion.
verses.comment: External beauty without virtue is ultimately out of place and wasted.

verses.text: The desire of the righteous ends only in good, but the expectation of the wicked in wrath.
verses.comment: Righteousness is always fruitful while wickedness returns only judgment.

verses.text: One gives freely and grows all the richer; another withholds what is right and only suffers want.
verses.comment: God’s economy rewards generosity, anticipating the principle Christ taught about giving and receiving.

verses.text: A generous soul will prosper, and whoever refreshes others will himself be refreshed.
verses.comment: Spiritual and material generosity brings mutual blessing. Generosity is a virtue at the heart of the gospel.

verses.text: The people will curse whoever withholds grain, but blessing will be on the head of the one who sells it.
verses.comment: Hoarding resources harms the community, while just trade is a blessing, reflecting the call to serve rather than exploit others.

verses.text: Whoever seeks good finds favor, but evil comes to one who searches for it.
verses.comment: Intentions direct outcomes. Seeking good—ultimately, seeking God—leads to blessing.

verses.text: Whoever trusts in riches will fall, but the righteous will flourish like a green leaf.
verses.comment: Trust in wealth is insecure; trust in God gives stability. This is echoed by Christ’s teachings about treasure (Matt. 6:19–21).

verses.text: Whoever troubles his own house will inherit nothing, and the fool will be servant to the wise of heart.
verses.comment: Mismanagement and folly bring emptiness; wisdom ultimately prevails.

verses.text: The fruit of the righteous is a tree of life, and the one who wins souls is wise.
verses.comment: Righteous living bears fruit for others, and drawing people to righteousness is itself the highest wisdom, echoing evangelistic and spiritual themes in the New Testament.

verses.text: If the righteous are repaid on earth, how much more the wicked and the sinner!
verses.comment: Both reward and retribution can be seen in this life, but the final fulfillment awaits God’s judgment, reminding us to look beyond immediate circumstances.
